answers.author: Tom Jenkins
answers.text:
I'm aware of no such list.  The standard you're likely looking for is NFPA 1710.  You might start by looking at accredited fire agencies 
at 
http://www.publicsafetyexcellence.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=Zu228Vbl0l0%3d&tabid=71
Although these agencies might not comply with the requirements is all geographic areas of their city or in the response time segments (call processing, turnout, travel, ERF travel) they are going to be among the few political jurisdictions measuring the data at regular intervals.

answers.author: Thomas Wieczorek
answers.text:
As noted by Chief Jenkins, I believe you are going to want to review NFPA 1710 rather than NFPA 1720 for compliance issues. NFPA 1710 pertains only to all-career departments; 1720 pertains to volunteer, combination, public safety and any other department outside of all-career. 
Both standards are voluntary and not mandated to be adopted. Also remember that neither standard should be looked at from simply the standpoint of response time; in many cases response time (particularly in EMS) has no affect on outcomes and hurrying may actually increase the liability and risk to a community.  Both standards require a community to conduct an all-hazard, all-risk analysis, review data and calls for service, and deploy resources matching the risk and hazards with acceptable performance as promulgated by the authority having jurisdiction. The AHJ determines the acceptable deployment methodology meeting the needs desired or expected by the community. Response time is but one metric to analyze performance.  
I would agree that the Center for Public Safety Excellence, Inc. (CPSE) and its fire accreditation may be a good place to find comparables. However, comparing only on a response time basis could result in deploying resources in an unsustainable method. In addition to response time, an analysis should also look at workload, calls, resource exhaustion, mitigation, and alternative service delivery models. Getting to the scene in 4 minutes may or may not result in a successful outcome if the Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA) patient is on the 26th floor of a building, requires extrication, or if the notification for a responding vehicle took a lengthy amount of time. The 1720 model does incorporate some good methodology for community risk reduction and assessment while the 1710 standard focuses more on the time and staffing elements. CPSM is always available to assist communities with this analytical process using a managerial approach.

answers.author: Nikiah Nudell
answers.text:
You're looking for a 'list' but such a list does not exist. You will find each city/county produces their own reports and data for the public and in some cases they use varying definitions of "response times". There are many ways to slice the data and to present it depending on who the audience is.
Are you looking to develop compliance standards for your city? The NFPA standards are designed for/by fire based systems which are wholly different than third service, public utility model, or contracted services. There are other issues of urbanicity as well as first responder utilization, ALS vs BLS, transport agency configuration, etc to consider as well.
Cheers,
Nick

Nick Nudell, MS, NRP
Chief Data Officer
PrioriHealth Partners, LLP.
(760) 405-6869
nick@priorihealth.com
www.priorihealth.com

answers.author: PATRICK COUGHLIN
answers.text:
Inquire at the US Fire Administration and the National Fire Prevention Association. Both organizations have stated that two thirds of fire departments do not comply with NFPA 1710 (which applies to career fire departments). They must have raw data that lead to that conclusion, but I do not believe that either organization has published any data that controlled for variables such as size of population served, etc.

author: Eileen Lipinski
text: The City of Milwaukee is looking for a list of municipal fire departments that meet or exceed the National Standard EMS and fire response time as regulated by NFPA 1720.  Ideally we would like to see a list for cities of similar size to Milwaukee, populations of 500,000 or greater.  If anyone is aware of such a list I would appreciate being contacted with that information.
title: Standard EMS and Fire Response Times
